## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 24, 2024 - January 30, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-31T21:52:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-01-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240131-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 6 M-class flares, 10 C-type CMEs, and 3 O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z may give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-31T08:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-4 (below minor) (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-01-27T03:36Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-29T18:19Z (see notification 20240127-AL-001).
2024-01-27T04:24Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-29T18:19Z (see notification 20240127-AL-001).
2024-01-28T02:48Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-30T16:00Z (glancing blow).
2024-01-29T02:00Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T09:52Z (see notification 20240129-AL-010).
2024-01-29T04:38Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T09:52Z, STEREO A at 2024-01-31T04:02Z, Mars at 2024-02-02T02:00Z (glancing blow), and Lucy at 2024-02-02T23:43Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010).
2024-01-30T00:24Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-01T14:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240130-AL-002).
2024-01-30T21:12Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-01T05:42Z (see notification 20240131-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

There was a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES. At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-29T05:11Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-002 and 20240129-AL-004). At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-29T06:08Z (see notification 20240129-AL-007). At GOES, the integral flux of the >10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-01-29T06:15Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-006 and 20240129-AL-008). This solar energetic particle event is associated with the M6.8 flare peaking at 2024-01-29T04:38Z from Active Region 13559 (N25W70) (see notifications 20240129-AL-001 and 20240129-AL-003) and subsequent O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010). The enhanced particle environment at STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES began to notably subside on 2024-01-30, decreasing below each spacecraftÂ’s respective threshold and remaining slightly elevated above background levels through the end of the reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-02-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There are currently five Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13559 and 13561, which were responsible for multiple M-class flares observed during the reporting period, have rotated off the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13567 (N20E58) has produced several C-class flares since rotating onto the Earth-facing disk around 2024-01-30 and may continue to exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity could be observed on or around 2024-02-01 due to a possible glancing blow from the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (previously described above). Additionally, coronal hole structures currently centered near S18W20 and S35E15 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective during the outlook period on or around 2024-02-02 and 2024-02-04, respectively. 

## Notes:

R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-31T11:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~902 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 16 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 107/13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-31T11:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Lucy (minor impact) and OSIRIS-APEX.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-02-08T10:00Z and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-02T10:31Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-30T00:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~563 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 18 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 80/26 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-30T00:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact OSIRIS-APEX (glancing blow). The flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-01T14:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2024-01-30T00:24:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2024-01-30T00:24:00-CME-001) is associated with C1.9 flare with ID 2024-01-30T00:07:00-FLR-001 from AR 13559 (N31W78) which peaked at 2024-01-30T00:16Z.


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

Note that while this SEP event was unfolding, there was a large data gap in STEREO A Beacon data from 2024-01-29T13:45Z to 2024-01-30T01:59Z. Once Beacon data returned, the 13-100 MeV proton flux was still above threshold which triggered an automatic notification with ID 20240130-AL-001 (see below). This additional notification is related to the same SEP event at STEREO A with Activity ID: 2024-01-29T05:11:00-SEP-001 and does not represent a separate SEP event.

## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240129-AL-009), now simulated with CME with ID 2024-01-29T02:00:00-CME-001.

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-29T02:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~936 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 65/12 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-29T02:00:00-CME-001

2: O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-29T04:38Z.

Estimated speed: ~1277 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 54 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 64/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the combined leading edge of CME with ID 2024-01-29T02:00:00-CME-001 and CME with ID 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 may impact OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T09:52Z (plus minus 7 hours). Additionally, the leading edge or flank of the CME with ID 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 may impact Lucy at 2024-02-02T23:43Z, STEREO A at 2024-01-31T04:02Z, and Mars (glancing blow) at 2024-02-02T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours).

The simulation also indicates that the CME with ID 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-31T08:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor).

## Notes: 

Updated CME analysis and simulation results for CME with ID: 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 do not show an impact to Psyche, as previously indicated in a prior notification (see notification 20240129-AL-009).

The CME with ID 2024-01-29T02:00:00-CME-001 is associated with the M1.2 flare with ID 2024-01-29T01:29:00-FLR-001 from Active Region 13559 (N30W61) which peaked at 2024-01-29T01:40Z.

The CME with ID 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001 is associated with the M6.8 flare with ID 2024-01-29T03:54:00-FLR-001 from Active Region 13559 (N25W70) which peaked at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-001 and 20240129-AL-003), SEP at STEREO A with ID 2024-01-29T05:11:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20240129-AL-002 and 20240129-AL-004), modeled SEP prediction from REleASE: ACE/EPAM 15.8-39.8 MeV with ID 2024-01-29T05:50:00-SEP-001 (see notification 20240129-AL-005), SEP at SOHO: COSTEP 15.8-39.8 MeV with ID 2024-01-29T06:06:00-SEP-001, SEP at SOHO: COSTEP 28.2-50.1 MeV with ID 2024-01-29T06:08:00-SEP-001 (see notification 20240129-AL-007), and SEP at GOES-P with ID 2024-01-29T06:15:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20240129-AL-006 and 20240129-AL-008).

## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-29T04:38Z.

Estimated speed: ~1278 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 52 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 58/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-29T04:38:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Lucy, OSIRIS-APEX, STEREO A, Mars (glancing blow), and Psyche (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME may reach Lucy at 2024-02-03T05:36Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T12:24Z, STEREO A at 2024-01-31T01:34Z, Mars at 2024-02-02T11:00Z, and Psyche at 2024-02-02T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-31T06:17Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).

## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by GOES. The flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeds 10 pfu starting at 2024-01-29T06:15Z.

NASA spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-01-29T06:15:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

Earlier solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A (see notifications 20240129-AL-002 and 20240129-AL-004), detected by SOHO (see notification 20240129-AL-007), and modeled with MODEL: REleASE:ACE/EPAM 15.8-39.8 MeV (see notification 20240129-AL-005).

This SEP event (2024-01-29T06:15:00-SEP-001) is associated with M6.8 flare from AR 13559 (N25W70) with ID 2024-01-29T03:54:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-001 and 20240129-AL-003).

An associated CME first seen at 2024-01-29T04:38Z has also been detected in STEREO COR2A images with a plane-of-sky shock speed of approximately 1400-1500 km/s. Updates will be provided when available.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

A solar energetic particle event was detected by SOHO. The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-22T13:42Z (see notification 20240122-AL-002). This solar energetic particle event may be associated with the C4.0 flare peaking at 2024-01-21T00:27Z and C5.3 flare peaking at 2024-01-21T00:41Z from Active Region 13559 and subsequent O-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery at 2024-01-21T00:36Z (see notification 20240121-AL-001). The proton flux may have been further enhanced by the M1.5 flare which peaked at 2024-01-22T06:22Z from Active Region 13559. The energetic proton flux of the >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A were elevated during the reporting period, but remained below their respective thresholds of 10 pfu and 10^(-1) pfu/MeV. The particle environment subsided to background levels at all locations on 2024-01-23.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at SOHO.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-01-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently seven Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13559 (currently located at N27W12) and Active Region 13561 (currently located at S17W52) produced M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels for the upcoming week. An increase in geomagnetic activity may be observed in the beginning of the outlook period due to the anticipated arrival on 2024-01-25 of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-22T10:48Z, the combined arrivals on 2024-01-26 of the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-22T22:36Z and 2024-01-23T04:12Z, and possible glancing blow arrivals on 2024-01-26 and 2024-01-27 from C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-01-23T03:48Z and 2024-01-23T17:36Z, respectively. Additionally, two coronal holes currently centered around N40E30 and S16E30 (as seen in available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-01-28.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-01-23T03:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~771 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -9/46 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-01-23T03:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Psyche (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Psyche at 2024-01-28T09:00Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-26T00:30Z, and STEREO A at 2024-01-26T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-26T17:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).

The proton fluxes at SOHO and GOES subsided to below their respective threshold levels on 2024-01-05. The energetic particle fluxes at all three locations have since decreased to background levels.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 27, 2023 - January 02, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-03T23:26:36Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-12-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-01-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240103-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare and 4 M-class flares (see list below). There were 13 C-type CMEs and 1 R-type CME (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the R-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-12-31T22:00Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-02T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20240101-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was possibly detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-01-03T04:50Z (see notification 20240103-AL-002). Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing. 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-12-27T01:48Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-12-28T18:31Z (see notification 20231227-AL-001).
2023-12-27T04:00Z Mars at 2023-12-31T19:00Z (glancing blow).
2023-12-31T10:00Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-01T23:31Z (see notification 20231231-AL-001).
2023-12-31T22:00Z Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-02T07:00Z, Juno at 2024-01-11T00:18Z, Psyche at 2024-01-03T12:30Z (glancing blow), STEREO A at 2024-01-02T23:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240101-AL-001).
2024-01-02T11:09Z OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-04T06:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-01-07T03:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240102-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.00 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

During the reporting period, there was a solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO. At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-02T23:22Z (see notification 20240103-AL-001). This solar energetic particle event may be associated with an X5.0 flare from AR 13536 (N04E80) which peaked at 2023-12-31T21:55Z (see notifications 20231231-AL-002 and 20231231-AL-003) along with an associated R-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-12-31T22:00Z (see notification 20240101-AL-001). The observed elevation in one or more of the >15.8 MeV proton channels was gradual and continued to oscillate around the 10^(-1) pfu/MeV threshold through the end of the reporting period. Analysis of this SEP event and all possibly associated activity is ongoing. The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons detected at STEREO A were elevated above background levels during the latter part of the reporting period but did not exceed their respective thresholds of 10 pfu and 10^(-1) pfu/MeV before the end of the reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at SOHO.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-01-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are four numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13536 (N05E37) was responsible for the notable X-class and M-class flares observed during the reporting period and this region may continue to exhibit additional flaring activity as it transits the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole structure centered near S30E28 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) could become geoeffective during the latter part of the outlook period on or around 2023-01-07. Recently, the flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES exceeded the threshold of 10 pfu starting at 2024-01-03T20:05Z (see notifications 20240103-AL-003 and 20240103-AL-004). The >10 MeV integral proton flux at GOES is currently sustained above or near the 10 pfu threshold and this elevation may persist throughout the beginning part of the outlook period.

## Summary:

R-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-12-31T22:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~2184 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -60/-14 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-12-31T22:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Solar Orbiter, Juno, Psyche (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME may reach Solar Orbiter at 2024-01-02T07:00Z, Juno at 2024-01-11T00:18Z, Psyche at 2024-01-03T12:30Z, and STEREO A at 2024-01-02T23:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-02T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
